The Minister of Home Security said that Merseyside had suffered from air attacks on the previous four nights, the attacks onthe Saturday and Sunday being particularly heavy.The casualties at Merseyside had been: Friday: Killed, 105; Injured, 191.Saturday (estimated): Killed, 463; Injured, 734.Sunday : No report available.Repeated attacks on towns of moderate size presented manydifficult problems. At Plymouth, for example, many people had to evacuate the town at night as no living quarters were available, butthey found that most of the billets outside the town were filled withevacuees from London. The question of reserving a belt round suchtowns free from evacuees from other parts of the country was being examined.Other places attacked during the last four nights includedPortsmouth, Tyneside, Barrow-in-Furness and Belfast.[22486] I*i4.wn,r- r,i g2%? On the-4th March they had returned to the charge, and weFrance. had agreed to the sailing of two wheat ships, subject to assurances(Previous that the entry of further Germans into French Africa should be reference;: forbidden, the activities of the Armistice Commission limited, andW.M. (41) 30th certain British Consular Officers allowed to return.Conclusions, When the Vichy-German barter agreement had been made.Minute 3.) towards the end of March, whereby Vichy was to obtain 800,000 tonsof wheat against certain foodstuffs from the unoccupied zone, wehad pressed the United States Government to drop the proposals forfurther supplies, but had indicated that we would adhere to our, decision to let these two cargoes proceed.On the 28th March the State Department had told us that they: intended these two ships to proceed, hut did not contemplateapproaching tas further for the present as regards shipments toFrance.On the 30th April our Ambassador had been informed by thei State Department that they had agreed in principle with a proposal of the French Government that two further wheat ships should besent to unoccupied France as soon as possible, by early July at the: latest, and that the United States Government should have complete- control of the disposal of the wheat and facilities for appointing: ' \ controllers. It appeared that the United States government intended to send further shipments :(two ships at a time) on similar'' ' - lines, if a satisfactory report was received on the distribution of the.; " first two cargoes.Looked at from the blockade point of view, we had made' ;:l concessions without any substantial quid pro quo. The attitude ofthe State Department in making this arrangement without prior consulation with us was hardly consistent with the previous negotiations on the matter.On the other hand, the Prime Minister pointed out that, owingto other demands on our Naval forces, we were not maintaining an effective blockade of unoccupied France. After discussion between the Ministers concerned, it had been decided not to take a stiff line with the United States Government on the matter. Lord Halifaxhad been instructed to say that we hoped that the United StatesGovernment would not think it necessary to despatch these two ships'at once, and that no publicity should be given to the contemplatedshipments for the present. He should also say that we attached importance to the appointment of controllers in order to introduce a body of observers into unoccupied France.The War Cabinet took note of, and endorsed, the line ofaction taken in these instructions.Gibraltar. 6. The main point at issue was whetherReference: they should be brought to this country, notwithstanding the incon-W.M. (40) 277th conveniences to which this would give rise, or should be sent to Jamaica.Conclusions, The War Cabinet agreed as follows :-Minute 5.) to(1) Of these 4,000 civilians, 2,200 were dockyard workers and could not be spared immediately. As many as possible of the remaining 1,800 should be brought here in a shipor ships which should be diverted to Gibraltar for thispurpose on the homeward journey from the Middle East.(2) The possibility of providing an escort for a ship carryingout this duty should be settled between the Sea TransportDivision of the Ministry of Shipping and the Operations(Foreign) Division of the Admiralty.(3) The remaining civilians in Gibraltar should be evacuated,as they could be spared, and as shipping could be madeavailable.
